body.p: An Associated Press article captured the attention of readers with the headline "Night lights bad for kids?" The article was based on a 1999 study at the University of Pennsylvania and Children's Hospital of Philadelphia, in which parents were surveyed about the lighting conditions under which their children slept between birth and age 2 (lamp, night light, or no light) and whether or not their children developed nearsightedness (myopia). The purpose of the study was to explore the effect of a young child's nighttime exposure to light on later nearsightedness.
In this activity, we use the collected data to:

ul.li: Learn how to build a two-way table and compute conditional percentages.
Interpret the data in terms of the relationship between a young child's nighttime exposure to light and later nearsightedness.

The data have been loaded into the data frame nightlight. Enter the command nightlight to see the data. There are two variables: Light and Nearsightedness.

You should see a report about 479 subjects with two columns. The first column records what kind of light, if any, was used in the subjects’ bedrooms while they slept, and the second column indicates whether or not the subjects later became nearsighted.

alternative.title: StatCrunch Instructions
alternative.p: To open this file in StatCrunch you must first right-click here and choose "Save Target As" to download the file to your computer. Next click hereto open StatCrunch in a separate window and login using your username and password.

ul.li: Click on the link "Open StatCrunch" at the top of the My StatCrunch page.
To open the data set, select the "My computer" link under "Load a data set" from box on the left side of the page.
Select the "Browse" or "Choose File" (depending on which browser you're using) and select the data set you downloaded.
Scroll to the bottom of the page and click on "Load File."

alternative.p: To ask StatCrunch for a two-way table that contains both the counts and conditional percentages:

ul.li: Choose: Stat → Tables → Contingency → with data.
Row variable: Light, Column Variable: Nearsightedness.
Press Next.
Check: Row percent. Uncheck all other options.
Press Calculate.

alternative.title: Minitab Instructions
alternative.p: To open Minitab with the data in the worksheet, right-click here and choose "Save Target As" to download the file to your computer. Then find the downloaded file and double-click it to open it in Minitab. Note: you will likely see a dialog box appear that says "A copy of the content of this file will be added to the current project"—just click OK.
To ask Minitab for a two-way table that contains both the counts and conditional percentages:

ul.li: Choose: Stat → Tables → Cross Tabulation and Chi-Square.

Under "Categorical Variables":
Next to "For rows" enter the explanatory variable ("Light" in this case).
Next to "For columns" enter the response variable ("Nearsightedness" in this case).
Under "Display" check "Counts" and "Row percents."
Click OK. (A two-way table will appear in the session (upper) window. Note the "Cell Contents" below the table, which tells you what the two entries in each cell in the table are.)

alternative.title: Excel 2013 and 2016 Instructions
alternative.p: To open the dataset, click here to download the file to your computer. Then find the downloaded file and double-click it to open it in Excel. When Excel opens you may have to enable editing.
To create a two-way table in Excel:
First we need to sort our data to make it easier to tabulate:

ul.li: Type Control-A twice to select all of the data in the worksheet.
Choose Sort & Filter → Custom Sort from the Editing group in the Home tab.
In the pop-up window, make sure that My data has headers is checked and then choose light from the pull-down menu next to Sort by.
Click the Add Level button and then choose nearsightedness from the pull-down menu next to Sort by in the new row that was just added. Click OK.

alternative.p: Now we'll create our two-way table. First we'll make the row and column headings and then use Excel formulas to get the counts:

ul.li: Pick a cell outside of the two columns of data, and type Statistic. Then move to the right one cell and type No, move right and type Yes, and move right and type Total for our column headings.
For the row headings, start in the cell under Statistic and type lamp, then move down one cell and type night-light, move down and type no light, and move down and type Total.
Now select the cell under No and to the right of lamp, and type =counta(B2:B35).
Move one cell to the right (under Yes and to the right of lamp) and type =counta(B36:B76). Repeat this for each cell in the table, adjusting the data range appropriately.

To fill in the Total column you can use the sum function. For example, to fill in the cell under Total and to the right of Lamp you could type =sum(F3,G3) where F3 and G3 refer to the counts you calculated for Lamp from before (your cell locations may be different based on where you put your table in Excel).

alternative.p: To create a table of conditional percentages, we'll make a new table underneath the two way-table, and use the same row and column labels as the two-way table.

ul.li: Pick a cell underneath the two-way table, and type the same row and column labels in that we used for the two-way table.

Now select the cell under No and to the right of lamp. In this cell, we want the percentage of children who slept with a lamp and did not develop nearsightedness. Thus, we want to divide the number of children who slept with a lamp and did not develop nearsightedness by the total number of children who slept with a lamp, and then multiply by 100 to convert to a percentage. The specific cell references depend on where exactly you created your two-way table, but if cell location D2 represents the number of children who slept with a lamp and did not develop nearsightedness, and cell location F2 represents the total number of children who slept with a lamp, the formula would be =(D2/F2)*100.
Calculate the percentages for the other cells in the same manner.

alternative.title: TI Instructions
alternative.p: Important Note! TI 83/84 calculators do not have the built-in capability to create a table of counts and percents or to construct a pie chart. Thus, for this activity, we suggest trying one of the other technologies available in OLI Statistics. R is an excellent statistical package that is free to download and that is available for both Windows and Mac OS X.
If you want to continue with the TI Calculator, you can produce a two-way table by hand using your TI to help.

To open a group of lists with the night-light data loaded, right-click here and choose "Save Target As" to download the file to your computer. Then find the downloaded file and send it to your calculator. For instructions on how to connect your calculator to your computer and transfer a file, click here.

You have stacked data in two lists: one for the explanatory variable Lightand one for the response variable Nearsightedness. The explanatory variable is sorted by category, and then the response variable has been sorted for each category of the explanatory variable:

ul.li: L1: Light (0 = no light, 1 = night-light, 2 = lamp). This list is sorted.
L2: Nearsightedness (0 = No, 1 = Yes). This list is sorted separately for each category of the explanatory variable Light.
To access one of the built-in lists, press 2ND and then the number of the list, followed by ENTER. For example, to access L1, you would press 2ND/1/ENTER.
Use the right and left arrows to scroll through the list.
You can also choose Stat/Edit/1:Edit to see the lists in table form. You can scroll through the table using the arrow keys.

alternative.p: For each category of the explanatory variable, count the data values in each category of the response variable.
The page Module 2, Case C → C (2 of 2) describes how to create a two-way table with counts and with percentages.
